title: Greens (South Tyrol)
text:
The Greens ("––") are a <a href="Regionalism%20%28politics%29">regionalist</a>, <a href="green%20politics">green</a> <a href="list%20of%20political%20parties%20in%20South%20Tyrol">political party</a> (with <a href="Eco-socialism">eco-socialist</a> and self-proclaimed <a href="Social%20democracy">social-democratic</a> tendencies) active in <a href="South%20Tyrol">South Tyrol</a>, northern <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. Once the provincial section of the <a href="Federation%20of%20the%20Greens">Federation of the Greens</a>, the party is now autonomous and often forms different alliances at the country-level (most recently with <a href="Left%20Ecology%20Freedom">Left Ecology Freedom</a>, <a href="Italian%20Left">Italian Left</a> and <a href="Free%20and%20Equal%20%28Italy%29">Free and Equal</a>, while the Italian Greens have sided with <a href="Civil%20Revolution">Civil Revolution</a> and the <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28Italy%29">Democratic Party</a>), but both joined <a href="Green%20Europe">Green Europe</a>, a coalition of green parties for the <a href="2019%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">2019 European Parliament election</a>.
The Greens are inter-ethnic and strive to improve relations between the three language groups of the Province: <a href="Italian%20language">Italian-</a>, <a href="German%20language">German-</a> and <a href="Ladin%20language">Ladin-speakers</a>. Since 2019 the party's spokespersons have been <a href="Felix%20Wohlgemuth">Felix Wohlgemuth</a> and <a href="Marlene%20Pernstich">Marlene Pernstich</a>.
History.
The Greens have their roots in the <a href="New%20Left">New Left</a> and the <a href="environmental%20movement">environmental movement</a>s of the 1970s. They started to compete in elections in 1978, but were formally registered as a party only in 1996. From 1978 to 1996 they used different names: <a href="New%20Left%20%28Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%29">New Left</a> (<a href="1978%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20regional%20election%23South%20Tyrol">1978</a>), Alternative List (<a href="1983%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20regional%20election%23South%20Tyrol">1983</a>), Green Alternative List (<a href="1988%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20regional%20election%23South%20Tyrol">1988</a>) and finally Greens (since <a href="1993%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20regional%20election%23South%20Tyrol">1993</a>). One of the founders and most active members of the Greens was <a href="Alexander%20Langer">Alexander Langer</a>, who committed suicide in 1995.
Other than in the <a href="Landtag%20of%20South%20Tyrol">Landtag of South Tyrol</a>, the party was successively represented in the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a> by Langer (1989–1995) and mountaineer <a href="Reinhold%20Messner">Reinhold Messner</a> (1999–2004).
In the <a href="2003%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20provincial%20elections%23South%20Tyrol">2003 provincial election</a> the party obtained 7.9% of the vote and three provincial councillors: <a href="Cristina%20Kury">Cristina Kury</a>, <a href="Sepp%20Kusstatscher">Sepp Kusstatscher</a> (a former member of the <a href="South%20Tyrolean%20People%27s%20Party">South Tyrolean People's Party</a>, SVP) and <a href="Hans%20Heiss">Hans Heiss</a>.
In the <a href="2004%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">2004 European Parliament election</a>, the Greens won 13.1% of the vote in the Province, their best result ever, and sent Kusstatscher to the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a>, replacing Messner.
In the <a href="2008%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20provincial%20elections%23South%20Tyrol">2008 provincial election</a> the Greens won only the 5.8% of the vote, losing votes (-2.1%) and one seat from 2003. The two elected Green councillors were Heiss and <a href="Riccardo%20Dello%20Sbarba">Riccardo Dello Sbarba</a>, who succeeded to Kusstatscher.
In the <a href="2013%20Italian%20general%20election%20in%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">2013 general election</a> the Greens did not follow the national party into the <a href="Civil%20Revolution">Civil Revolution</a> alliance and decided instead to support <a href="Left%20Ecology%20Freedom">Left Ecology Freedom</a> (SEL), which included Green <a href="Florian%20Kronbichler">Florian Kronbichler</a> in its slate. Kronbichler was the first German-speaking South Tyrolean to be elected in a list different from SVP's.
In the <a href="2013%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20provincial%20elections%23South%20Tyrol">2013 provincial election</a> the Greens won 8.7% of the vote (+2.9%), their record high in a provincial election, and sent three elects to the Provincial Council: Heiss, Dello Sbarba and <a href="Brigitte%20Foppa">Brigitte Foppa</a>.
In the <a href="2014%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">2014 European Parliament election</a> the Greens supported <a href="The%20Other%20Europe">The Other Europe</a>, an electoral alliance launched by <a href="Italian%20Left">Italian Left</a> (SI, successor of SEL) and other left-wing parties, but its candidate <a href="Oktavia%20Brugger">Oktavia Brugger</a> was not elected. In the 2015 municipal election in <a href="Merano">Merano</a>, the second-largest South Tyrolean city, Green <a href="Paul%20R%C3%B6sch">Paul Rösch</a> was elected mayor with 60.7% of the vote in the run-off: it was the first time that the Greens were to win a large municipality.
In the <a href="2018%20Italian%20general%20election%20in%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">2018 general election</a> Kronbichler did not stand again and the Greens continued to join forces with SI within the <a href="Free%20and%20Equal%20%28Italy%29">Free and Equal</a> electoral list, with <a href="Norbert%20Lantschner">Norbert Lantschner</a> as its standard-bearer. Lantschner was not elected and the Greens lost their representation in Parliament.
In the <a href="2018%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20provincial%20elections%23South%20Tyrol">2018 provincial election</a> the Greens won 6.8% of the vote (-1.9pp) and again sent three elected to the Provincial Council.
In the run-up to the <a href="2019%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">2019 European Parliament election</a> the Greens joined the <a href="Green%20Europe">Green Europe</a> electoral list, with <a href="Norbert%20Lantschner">Norbert Lantschner</a> as their candidate.
In November 2019 the party became a full member of the <a href="European%20Green%20Party">European Green Party</a>.
In the <a href="2019%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">2019 European Parliament election</a> the Greens were part of the <a href="Green%20Europe">Green Europe</a> list, which obtained 8.7% in South Tyrol.
Popular support.
In the <a href="2013%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol%20provincial%20elections%23South%20Tyrol">provincial election in 2013</a> the Greens won 8.7% of the vote. They obtained their highest shares in five small municipalities: <a href="Urtij%C3%ABi">Urtijëi</a> (13.9%), <a href="Bronzolo">Bronzolo</a> (13.7%), <a href="Montan">Montan</a> (12.8%), <a href="Auer%2C%20South%20Tyrol">Auer</a> (12.4%) and <a href="Glurns">Glurns</a> (11.7%). Despite this, the party was usually stronger in cities than in rural areas: it did well in the three largest cities (11.4% in <a href="Bolzano">Bolzano</a>, 10.6% in <a href="Merano">Merano</a> and 11.0% in <a href="Brixen">Brixen</a>), while it did worse in the four most rural <a href="Districts%20of%20Trentino-Alto%20Adige/S%C3%BCdtirol">districts</a> – <a href="Vinschgau">Vinschgau</a> (7.3%, despite Glurns), <a href="Salten-Schlern">Salten-Schlern</a> (7.2%, despite Urtijëi), <a href="Pustertal">Pustertal</a> (6.9%, despite 11.6% in <a href="Bruneck">Bruneck</a>) and <a href="Wipptal">Wipptal</a> (6.5%) – and in <a href="Ladin%20language">Ladin</a> municipalities (5.9%, despite Urtijëi).
Previous elections showed similar patterns of the vote.

Leadership.
Spokesperson: <a href="Carlo%20Bertorelle">Carlo Bertorelle</a> (1996–1998), <a href="Leander%20Moroder">Leander Moroder</a> (1998–2006), <a href="Franco%20Bernard">Franco Bernard</a> (2006–2009), <a href="Sepp%20Kusstatscher">Sepp Kusstatscher</a> and <a href="Brigitte%20Foppa">Brigitte Foppa</a> (2009–2013), <a href="Giorgio%20Zanvettor">Giorgio Zanvettor</a> and <a href="Brigitte%20Foppa">Brigitte Foppa</a> (2014–2016), <a href="Hans%20Heiss">Hans Heiss</a> and <a href="Brigitte%20Foppa">Brigitte Foppa</a> (2016–2017), <a href="Tobias%20Planer">Tobias Planer</a> and <a href="Brigitte%20Foppa">Brigitte Foppa</a> (2017–2019), <a href="Felix%20Wohlgemuth">Felix Wohlgemuth</a> and <a href="Marlene%20Pernstich">Marlene Pernstich</a> (2019–present)
